thread.title: Americans apologise to Australians for Trump's behaviour
thread.title_full: Americans apologise to Australians for Trump's behaviour | Daily Mail Online

author: Cindy Tran
title: Americans apologise to Australians for Trump's behaviour
text:
Americans have taken to social media to apologise for Donald Trump 's behaviour following a hostile phone call between the President and Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull .
Mr Trump and Mr Turnbull were speaking about a proposed asylum seeker deal over the weekend that would see the U.S. take in 1,250 refugees from Australia's offshore detention centres on Nauru and Manus Island.
But a fuming President Trump reportedly told Mr Turnbull the conversation was 'the worst call by far' he had taken that day and accused the Prime Minister of looking to ship off the 'next Boston bombers' to the US.
Americans have taken to social media to apologie for Donald Trump's (left) behaviour following a hostile phone call between the President and Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull (right)
After news emerged of the call, Americans apologised to Australians for the encounter between the two leaders
After news emerged, Americans apologised to Australians for the encounter between the two leaders whose first official television conversation ended just after 25 minutes.
'Dear good people of Australia: Donald trump does NOT represent or speak for me or millions of Americans. We apologise for this insanity...' one woman wrote on Twitter.
'Australia may be the single most effect and loyal ally of the U.S. this is no way to treat a true friend,' a professor wrote.
The Prime Minister and President were speaking about a proposed asylum seeker deal when their first official television conversation ended after only 25 minutes
American citizens called Mr Trump's 'barbaric' and said his behaviour is no way to treat a long-time ally
'To P.M. of Australia and all of its citizens and residents, please accpet my sincere apology for our President's barbaric conduct,' one man said.
'Dear Australia, Mexico, et al: please bear with us. We're embarassed and working on it. Sincerely, a majority of America,' another man wrote online.
It comes after White House Bureau Chief for The Washington Post Philip Rucker told the ABC News 24 the President 'doesnâ€™t really care so much that Australia is an ally over many, many years'.
'The thing you have to understand about Donald Trump is that he is not a natural diplomat, he is not a politician,' he said.
Americans and Australians alike began to poke fun of Mr Trump after the failed phone call in a series of memes on social media.
Many other people from around the world posted memes on social media in reaction to the call
Benjamin Northey shared a photograph of Roger the musclebound kangaroo crushing a metal bucket with its paws
'@realDonaldTrump Do NOT make Roger angry,' the post said on Twitter.
Jorge Ribas shared a GIF of the viral video of a man punching a kangaroo, with the captions: 'Before you pick a fight with Australia remember they punch kangaroos in the face like it's no big deal.'
One person urged President Donald Trump not to anger Roger, the very large kangaroo
Many are entertaining themselves with references from The Simpsons.
Brett Osborn posted: 'Exclusive footage of @TurnbullMalcolm standing up to Trump for Australia, with a GIF showing Nelson using Milson's hand to punch himself in the face, with the captions: 'Stop hitting yourself'.
In another hilarious tweet, Mitch Feltscheer shared a photo of the boy who answered Bart Simpson's phone call about the direction of Australia's toilet flush.
Andrew Brown shared a photo of President Trump appearing to show the middle finger when he was supposedly speaking to the Prime Minister
Peter Quote: : 'EXCLUSIVE: Photos from inside @TurnbullMalcolm's office, with a picture of a dog saying 'this is fine' as it sat in a burning room.
David Silverman shared a photo of cartoon character Ren from The Ren & Stimpy Show, screaming at the telephone and his hand hovering above a red button.
Greens Senator Scott Ludlam decided to comment on an old tweet from the PM, who congratulated President Trump recently for his new role.
'How's that working out?' Ludlam commented.
